folder: Stuyvesant Square Park & [Between 15th and 17th Streets (East).], Manhattan, NY
text:
Stuyvesant Square Park, looking northwest through the gate on 15th Street east of Second Avenue.
The Lying-In Hospital, on the N.W. corner of Second Avenue and 17th Street, is shown in the background.  Summer 1923.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Stuyvesant Square Park - [Between 15th and 17th Streets (East).]

text:
Second Avenue, west side, north from E. 16th Street, showing prominently the former Lying In Hospital occupying the frontage between 17th and 18th Streets. This structure, erected about 1900, stands on a site that included the Hamilton Fish residence.
In September of 1932, this organization will lose its identity on entering the new medical center of the N. Y. Hospital and Cornell Medical College on York Ave. In 1935 the Manhattan General Hospital will take over this building.
Views 2 and 3 are limited to the hospital building. Note the surface car and tracks. This line will be discontinued in 1933 and replaced by bus service.

P. L. Sperr
View 1 - Neg.# 4887
View 2 - Neg.# 793
View 3 - Neg.# 794

December 22, 1929
Views 1,2,3

folder: Stuyvesant Square Park & [Between 15th and 17th Streets (East).], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Stuyvesant Square Park: An open area between East 15th (right, southern boundary) and East 17th (left, northern boundary) Streets, that is bisected by Second Ave. The eastern side of same, as shown with the Beth Israel Hospital thereon, is Livingston Place. On the lower left appears the nave and bell-tower of St. Georges P.E. Church, located on the western edge, which is called Rutherford Place. This park, a portion of the former Stuyvesant Farm was bequeathed to the City by Peter Stuyvesant. The Park Department in conjunction with the W.P.A. attempted to improve same in 1936, as a playground for East Side children, but were restrained by the various hospitals in this vicinity. Their plea being based upon the original grant of land; "for park purposes." A judicial decree was granted in their favor. For further data, see newspapers for 1936-1937. Photographers vantage point is the Consolidated Edison Building, No. 4 Irving Place and shows an eastward perspective across the "Gas House" area of Manhattan to Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Separating these localities of the City is the East River.
September 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2 & 3)
Two similar views, taken the same day.
September 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Stuyvesant Square Park - [Between 15th and 17th Streets (East).]

folder: Stuyvesant Square Park & [Between 15th and 17th Streets (East).], Manhattan, NY
text:
Stuyvesant Park: A small park between E. 15th E 17th Streets, bisected by Second Avenue. Photo No. 1 is in a northwestward direction from a point near Second Ave. and 16th Street. At the left is the darkened shadow of St. George's Church on Rutherford Place. No. 2 is taken in the easterly half of the park and is southeastward in direction. The buildings there are on Livingston Place and run from 16th (left) to 15th Streets.
About 1935
No's. 1-2
Gift of the Committee on Housing
Charity Organization Society
title: Manhattan: Stuyvesant Square Park - [Between 15th and 17th Streets (East).]

text:
(1)
Second Avenue east side at 16th Street, showing Stuyvesant Park Square across the Parkway may be seen the N.Y. INfirmary for the Women and Childrens Dispensary.

(2)
Second Avenue, east side and north of 17th Street, showing at the southeast corner of 17th Street a bit of Stuyvesant Square.

P.L.Speer.

July 19, 1939.
